channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Deep orange skies, 'snowing' ash as fire smoke swamps Bay Area
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Susanne Rust
item.description: From San Francisco to Yosemite, social media was filled with images of ominous red and orange skies as smoke from a variety of fires blocked the sun.
item.content:encoded: From San Francisco to Yosemite, social media was filled with images of ominous red and orange skies as smoke from a variety of fires blocked the sun.

media:content.media:description: The scene this morning in Millbrae

item.title: 10 photos that give you a look at SoFi Stadium
item.dc:creator: Marc Martin
item.description: Photos of SoFi Stadium show the indoor-outdoor stadium in Inglewood that is the new home of the Rams and Chargers.
item.content:encoded: Photos of SoFi Stadium show the indoor-outdoor stadium in Inglewood that is the new home of the Rams and Chargers.

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: Los Angeles Rams and Los Angeles Chargers hosted the official ribbon-cutting ceremony for the new SoFi Stadium on Tuesday September 8, 2020 ahead of the inaugural first game as the Rams as hosts to the Cowboys this Sunday September 13, 2020, followed by the Chargers versus the Chiefs on September 20. The ceremony included Rams Owner/Chairman and SoFi Stadium and Hollywood Park developer E. Stanley Kroenke, Chargers Owner/Chairman Dean Spanos and the City of Inglewood's Mayor James T. Butts. The stadium is the first football stadium to be built within Los Angeles in Nearly 100 years. "We are in the team business, and you can't get to a moment like today without a great team. I would like to thank the 17,000 people who have worked on this project over the past four years," said Rams Owner/Chairman Stan Kroenke. "During a period of unrest and change in many parts of the country, it's been our deepest privilege to work on a project this special with such a diverse workforce. Thank you for making our vision a reality." SoFi Stadium is the first indoor-outdoor stadium and seats approximately 70,000, expandable up to 100,000. SoFi Stadium is located at Hollywood Park, a near 300-acre sports and entertainment destination being developed by Kroenke in Inglewood and at 3.1 million square-foot SoFi Stadium is the largest stadium in the NFL. SoFi Stadium on Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020 in Inglewood, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Firefighters hurt after being forced to deploy cocoon shelter in Dolan fire are 'doing well'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Dakota Smith
item.description: Fourteen firefighters defending a ranger station in Los Padres National Forest had to deploy a shelter. Three of them were hospitalized.
item.content:encoded: Fourteen firefighters defending a ranger station in Los Padres National Forest had to deploy a shelter. Three of them were hospitalized.

item.content:encoded: Riverside County Sheriff Chad Bianco said the illegal grow site appeared to be 'a very organized-crime type of an operation.'

(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: California's record-breaking wildfires continued to rage Tuesday even as authorities conceded they would get worse with downslope winds from Shasta to San Diego.

item.title: These hikers wanted a pandemic getaway. They ended up barely escaping the Creek fire
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: They were seeking fresh air, solitude and life away from coronavirus lockdowns. Instead, they got caught in a firestorm, some rescued by helicopter.
item.content:encoded: They were seeking fresh air, solitude and life away from coronavirus lockdowns. Instead, they got caught in a firestorm, some rescued by helicopter.

item.title: Most L.A. households face serious financial problems amid coronavirus pandemic, poll finds
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: The survey offers further proof that Black and Latino households often experience the heaviest financial fallout from the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The survey offers further proof that Black and Latino households often experience the heaviest financial fallout from the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 11: A couple in face masks walk down Cesar E. Chavez Blvd on Saturday morning in Los Angeles. Life around Cesar E. Chavez Blvd. and Soto St. has slow down as California officials extended stay-at-home orders into May and residents entered Easter weekend with unprecedented limits on their movements. Most of the people are adhering to the orders by mayor to wear masks while out running errands. Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Dozens arrested as protesters and deputies clash in Dijon Kizzee demonstrations in L.A.
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Demonstrations over the fatal shooting of Dijon Kizzee by L.A. County sheriff's deputies have turned chaotic, with deputies arresting dozens.
item.content:encoded: Demonstrations over the fatal shooting of Dijon Kizzee by L.A. County sheriff's deputies have turned chaotic, with deputies arresting dozens.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA SEPTEMBER 8, 2020: The Los Angeles Sheriff's Department declared an unlawful assembly and moved towards a crowd that gathered near the corner of Imperial Hwy and Normandy in Los Angeles, CA September 8, 2020. There have been three straight nights of protest outside the South LA Sheriff's station following the deadly deputy involved shooting of Dijan Kizzee. (Francine Orr/ Los AngelesTimes)

item.title: Housing costs for the homeless rose to $531,000 a unit, L.A. controller's report says
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: The average cost of projects funded by a $1.2-billion bond program have risen from $350,000 to $531,000.
item.content:encoded: The average cost of projects funded by a $1.2-billion bond program have risen from $350,000 to $531,000.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: A 49-unit project for homeless and disabled veterans under construction in Lake View Terrace has hit a construction cost of $739,000 a unit. Homeless housing construction costs average $531,000 a unit with a high of $746,000 a unit up from original projections of $350,000 a unit. Photographed at Lake View Terrace on Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In Point Reyes, all ears are tuned to local radio, a beacon amid the fog of fire
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: It's been a tense two weeks in a laid-back part of California, as Point Reyes residents try to keep track of a once-raging fire. The local radio station has been the glue.
item.content:encoded: It's been a tense two weeks in a laid-back part of California, as Point Reyes residents try to keep track of a once-raging fire. The local radio station has been the glue.

media:content.media:description: POINT REYES STATION, CA - AUGUST 28: Amanda Eichstaedt, the general manager at public radio station KWMR in Pt. Reyes Station on the Marin coast. When the pandemic hit, she was one of the few staffers to keep the station, a vital source of information, up and running. Now with fire threatening the area and her own home under evacuation warning, she is the sole staffer still keeping the signal going.Public Radio Station KWMR on Friday, Aug. 28, 2020 in Point Reyes Station, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sheriff's deputies and protesters clash again in South L.A. over shooting of Dijon Kizzee
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: For a fourth night Tuesday, protesters clashed with deputies outside a Los Angeles County Sheriff's station in South Los Angeles over the killing of Dijon Kizzee by two sheriff's deputies.
item.content:encoded: For a fourth night Tuesday, protesters clashed with deputies outside a Los Angeles County Sheriff's station in South Los Angeles over the killing of Dijon Kizzee by two sheriff's deputies.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA SEPTEMBER 8, 2020: The Los Angeles Sheriff's Department Declared an unlawful assembly and moved towards a crowd that gathered near the corner of Imperial Hwy and Normandy in Los Angeles, CA September 8, 2020. There have been three straight nights of protest outside the South LA Sheriff's station following the deadly deputy involved shooting of Dijan Kizzee. (Francine Orr/ Los AngelesTimes)

item.title: As COVID-19 risk dips, Orange County gets OK to reopen indoor restaurants, movie theaters
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Orange County joins San Diego as the only counties in Southern California not having "widespread risk" under the state's COVID-19 monitoring system.
item.content:encoded: Orange County joins San Diego as the only counties in Southern California not having "widespread risk" under the state's COVID-19 monitoring system.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - - A couple walk past a sign that reads, "Please Wear Mask," in front of Dash of Sass clothing store along Main Street during a "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus in the city of Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. Customers are not allowed into the store unless they are wearing a mask. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

The demonstration was held to hold the L.A. County Sheriff's Department accountable for the death of 29-year-old Dijon Kizzee whole was fatally by deputies after being stopped for an alleged vehicle code violation while biking on Aug. 30. item.title: California begins sending extra $900 to those unemployed due to COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California officials will mark the Labor Day holiday by sending a $900 supplemental unemployment benefit to jobless residents.
item.content:encoded: California officials will mark the Labor Day holiday by sending a $900 supplemental unemployment benefit to jobless residents.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this July 20, 2010 file photo, people arrive to seek employment opportunities at a JobTrain office in Menlo Park, Calif. On Monday, Aug. 24, 2020, Employment Development Department Director Sharon Hilliard told California lawmakers in Sacramento, California, the state has more than 1 million pending claims for unemployment benefits. Hilliard called the situation "shameful," but said the department is working through the backlog. (AP Photo/Paul Sakuma, File)

item.title: Los Angeles coronavirus toll declines, but officials warn of possible holiday spike
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: Health officials confirmed five new deaths and 798 new cases of COVID-19 in Los Angeles County, continuing a steady decline in the region's pandemic toll.
item.content:encoded: Health officials confirmed five new deaths and 798 new cases of COVID-19 in Los Angeles County, continuing a steady decline in the region's pandemic toll.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: All-time record heat across Southern California fuels fires, threatens power supply

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - SEP. 4, 2020. A blazing sun silhouettes power lines in North Long Beach ahead of a heatwave that is forecast to begin on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020. The weather event has the potential to set all-time record hot temperatures throughout Southern California through the Labor Day weekend. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Demonstration over Dijon Kizzee's fatal shooting ends with deputies, protesters clashing
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: At the demonstration, protesters called for police agencies to be defunded and residents to vote L.A. County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey out of office.
item.content:encoded: At the demonstration, protesters called for police agencies to be defunded and residents to vote L.A. County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey out of office.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 05: Protesters march in front of the South Los Angeles Sheriff's station to demand justice for Dijon Kizzee who was shot and killed by sheriff's deputies this week on Saturday, Sept. 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Sunday will be slightly hotter than Saturday in Southern California -- and that likely means more heat wave records.

item.content:encoded: At Mammoth Pool recreation area in the Sierra Nevada, a nighttime airlift rescued victims trapped by the Creek fire

item.title: Mojave Desert fire in August destroyed the heart of a beloved Joshua tree forest
item.dc:creator: Bettina Boxall
item.description: Wildfire burned one of the world's largest forests of Joshua trees, charring more than 1.3 million trees. The 43,273 acres of the Dome fire are forever transformed.
item.content:encoded: Wildfire burned one of the world's largest forests of Joshua trees, charring more than 1.3 million trees. The 43,273 acres of the Dome fire are forever transformed.

media:content.media:description: CIMA, CA - SEPTEMBER 01: Jacob "JT" Sohr, engine captain National Park Service, center, dwarfed by massive expanse of charred section of Mojave National Preserve. The Dome fire, one of the hundreds of wildfires that erupted during California's lightning siege, scorched 43,000 acres in the Mojave National Preserve, incinerating parts of the world's largest Joshua tree forest Mojave National Preserve on Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020 in Cima, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: For L.A. Latinos, Whittier Boulevard is still a crossroads of change and hope
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: For decades, Whittier Boulevard has been a hub of Latino life. Now the 14-mile thoroughfare is facing challenges from the pandemic and gentrification.
item.content:encoded: For decades, Whittier Boulevard has been a hub of Latino life. Now the 14-mile thoroughfare is facing challenges from the pandemic and gentrification.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 18, 2020. The sun sets on Whittier Boulevard in East Los Angeles, which has served as a hub of Latino life, commerce and culture for decades. The affordable shopping district and surrounding neighborhoods was fertile ground for an emerging, immigrant-rich middle class. Today, the heart of Whittier Blvd., from Atlantic Avenue on the west to Eastern Avenue on the east, is facing a new host of challenges from the coronavirus pandemic, economic meltdown and creeping gentrification. For many, this faded but resilient avenue remains a crossroads of change and hope. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 3.8 earthquake shakes the Santa Barbara area
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.8 earthquake was reported Saturday evening at 6:48 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from Goleta, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.8 earthquake was reported Saturday evening at 6:48 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from Goleta, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: COVID-19 deaths reach 6,000 in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Deaths caused by COVID-19 reached 6,000 in L.A. County, public health officials reported Saturday.
item.content:encoded: Deaths caused by COVID-19 reached 6,000 in L.A. County, public health officials reported Saturday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.description: How many more scorched summers can the king grape of Napa Valley survive?
item.content:encoded: How many more scorched summers can the king grape of Napa Valley survive?

media:content.media:description: San Juan Bautista, California,-Aug. 12, 2020-Tending so some young Grenache Nour vines, Randall Grahm is founder of Bonny Doon Vineyard. He is perhaps best known for his pioneering work with Rhone varietals in California. As the earth continues to heat up, and water tables decrease, hearty varieties of grapes will be important. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Is President Trump right? Are Democrats destroying our cities and states?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Trump's attack on Democrats ignores a few uncomfortable truths about his own actions and inactions.
item.content:encoded: Trump's attack on Democrats ignores a few uncomfortable truths about his own actions and inactions.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - JUNE 14, 2020 - - Thousands participate in the All Black Lives Matter solidarity march to mark LGBTQ Pride Month along Hollywood Blvd. in Hollywood on June 14, 2020. The march also honored Tony McDade, a transgender man killed by Tallahassee Police Department officers on May 27. The march is in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and highlight the contributions of people of color who were instrumental in organizing the LGBT movement, such as Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera. The procession started on Hollywood Boulevard at Highland Avenue in Hollywood. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. teachers union opposes opening campuses for students with disabilities, English learners
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: The L.A. teachers union on Friday announced that it opposes the return to campus of students with special needs â saying it isn't safe yet. And the union says schools can't bring teachers back without its approval.

Students were taking online courses due to the coronavirus pandemic and the campus was nearly empty. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'A forgotten city': An L.A. community beset by police violence and crime hopes for change
item.dc:creator: Nicole Santa Cruz, Ruben Vives
item.description: The small neighborhood of Westmont is in the spotlight after two police shootings there this year. But residents want officials bring something to the community they think is missing: a message of hope.
item.content:encoded: The small neighborhood of Westmont is in the spotlight after two police shootings there this year. But residents want officials bring something to the community they think is missing: a message of hope.

Budlong Avenue, where the 29-year-old Black man was shot and killed by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies. The shootting of Kizzee on Monday afternoon, Aug. 31, 2020, resulted in a standoff between protesters and police that continued into the night. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

Orange County residents will be able to get tested at no cost for COVID-19 at the Anaheim Convention Center starting today, July 15, 2020. Clinicians from 360 Clinic are administering the test kits, but citizens will do their own sample taking. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sentenced to life as a teen, Compton man to be freed after evidence is questioned
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: A Compton man who has spent nearly 20 years in prison for a shooting will be released after questions were raised about the evidence against him.
item.content:encoded: A Compton man who has spent nearly 20 years in prison for a shooting will be released after questions were raised about the evidence against him.

media:content.media:description: Emon Barnes, seen here as a teenager, was convicted of attempted murder in a Compton shooting at the age of 15. Attorneys from Loyola Marymount University's Project for the Innocence and L.A. County prosecutors teamed up to arrange for his release from San Quentin prison after questions were raised about the evidence against him.

item.title: Beach cities brace for crowds ahead of Labor Day weekend heat wave

item.content:encoded: With the holiday coinciding with a heat wave, Southern California's coastal communities are bracing for an influx of visitors.

media:content.media:description: Laura Martinez, 8, of Santa Ana, plays in spray pool to cool off as hundreds of people spread out over Mile Square Park to celebrate Labor Day with their families and got relief from the heat wave Monday, Sept. 7, 2020 in Fountain Valley.

item.title: USPS mail is found dumped at two spots in Glendale, prompting investigation
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Piles of unopened mail and packages were discovered at two locations near each other Thursday morning in Glendale. It is unclear whether the incidents are related.
item.content:encoded: Piles of unopened mail and packages were discovered at two locations near each other Thursday morning in Glendale. It is unclear whether the incidents are related.

media:content.media:description: San Pedro, California,-Aug. 20, 2020-A Los Angeles Postal carrier organizes mail to be delivered on Aug. 20, 2020. United States Postal Workers were offered 12 weeks leave due to the coronavirus pandemic, which caused a backlog of mail that needed to be delivered. Many postal carriers were offered overtime. A lack of enough postal carriers is one of the reasons that the United States Postal Service is behind on delivering mail. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: ICE arrests over 300 in L.A. area during month-long operation

item.content:encoded: The arrests included people convicted of battery, rape and kidnapping, said ICE, adding that, among those arrested locally, over 100 are now deported.

The man refused to come out and the team left. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

The vigil was held to honor the eight lives lost and hundreds of families impacted by a COVID-19 outbreak at Foster Farms' Livingston plant.

item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom declares a state of emergency as California utilities warn that sweltering conditions and increased demand could result in power outages.

The weather event has the potential to set all-time record hot temperatures throughout Southern California through the Labor Day weekend. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 2019: Vuong "Tom" Nguyen, 65, of Westminster, and a former South Vietnam soldier, leads a group of protestors in singing a patriotic song and using the timing of the Trump-Kim summit in Hanoi as leverage, hundreds of Vietnamese-Americans protest in Little Saigon to boost demand for human rights in their homeland. Photos taken in Westminster, Calif., on Feb. 26, 2019. Protestors marched from Lee's Sandwich to Asian Village and back. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Close-knit Latino family ties bring coronavirus dangers to traditional gatherings

He has gone to great efforts to keep his team safe from Covid-19. But things get complicated when it comes to family. His daughter lives in a different household. (Robert Gauthier/ Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 21: During the coronavirus global pandemic Sandy Valle, RN, left, Javier Gonzalez, EMT, middle, and Michelle Kim, RN, right, are working inside the triage tent at Martin Luther King, Jr., Community Hospital on Thursday, April 27, 2020 in the Willowbrook neighborhood located in South Los Angeles, CA. The international Medical Corps brought in this tent and it was places outside the Emergency Department at MLKCH. It's for ambulatory patients that have fever, cough, and shortness of breath, potential covid-19 symptoms. Dr. Oscar Casillas says, "We use the large tent to create more space and greater space between patients." (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

Wright Middle School in Calabasas. Las Virgenes School District employees on a voluntary basis were given a nasopharyngeal swab test to detect COVID-19 and also had their blood drawn to have it tested for antibodies to determine if they have had the coronavirus infection within the last 2 months. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Britney Spears doesn't want conservatorship case 'hidden away ... as a family secret'
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: In new court documents, Britney Spears supports the #FreeBritney movement and is 'vehemently opposed' to her father sealing her conservatorship case.
item.content:encoded: In new court documents, Britney Spears supports the #FreeBritney movement and is 'vehemently opposed' to her father sealing her conservatorship case.

media:content.media:description: The accusations in Sam Lutfi's case against Britney Spears' parents and her conservators may have been sensational, but the evidence just didn't hold up -- at least in the eyes of the judge, who tossed the suit Thursday before it made it to the jury. Lutfi's lawsuit had accused Britney's mom, Lynne Spears, of libel and her dad, Jamie Spears, of battery. It also accused her conservatorship of failing to pay him a 15% fee on the singer's income during the time he claimed to have been her manager. Full story: Judge boots case against Britney Spears' parents, conservatorship | Britney Spears' dad punched, threatened to kill me, Sam Lutfi says | PHOTOS: Celebrity meltdowns

item.title: Ferocious heat wave could bring record temperatures to California over Labor Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Temperatures are expected to climb 15 to 20 degrees above normal â and well into triple digits â in some areas of Southern California this weekend.
item.content:encoded: Temperatures are expected to climb 15 to 20 degrees above normal â and well into triple digits â in some areas of Southern California this weekend.

media:content.media:description: Laura Martinez, 8, of Santa Ana, plays in spray pool to cool off as hundreds of people spread out over Mile Square Park to celebrate Labor Day with their families and got relief from the heat wave Monday, Sept. 7, 2020 in Fountain Valley.

item.title: Search continues in Mexico for L.A. firefighter Garcetti said may have been kidnapped
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith, Kate Linthicum
item.description: Mayor Eric Garcetti said a missing L.A. firefighter may have been violently kidnapped in Baja California, but a prosecutor there could not confirm it.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Eric Garcetti said a missing L.A. firefighter may have been violently kidnapped in Baja California, but a prosecutor there could not confirm it.

media:content.media:description: Family members gathered for a vigil to pray for the safe return of a Los Angeles firefighter and Army veteran who disappeared last week in Mexico. Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarit

item.title: L.A. County is easing COVID-19 restrictions again: What you need to know
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Nina Agrawal, Howard Blume, Sonja Sharp
item.description: Health officials warn the reopenings come with warnings as the virus remains widespread in the community.
item.content:encoded: Health officials warn the reopenings come with warnings as the virus remains widespread in the community.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - APRIL 30: Senior Mason Wise, right, heads home with his sister Mackenzie, a sophomore, after gathering books and belongings out her lockers at El Camino Real Charter High School on Thursday, April 30, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. School officials were allowing no more than 5 students at a time on campus to take home their belongings. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California seeks immediate reversal of U.S. Postal Service changes
item.dc:creator: Maya Lau, Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Attorneys general from several states seek court order to force Trump administration to restore USPS operations
item.content:encoded: Attorneys general from several states seek court order to force Trump administration to restore USPS operations

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE-AUGUST 26, 2020: A mail carrier loads a truck for delivery at a United States Post Office in Torrance on Wednesday, August 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Eviction court is back. Financially struggling tenants remain protected, for now
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: California and the Trump administration issued protections this week that keep many tenants from losing their homes
item.content:encoded: California and the Trump administration issued protections this week that keep many tenants from losing their homes

media:content.media:description: Protestors held a press conference outside San Diego City Hall demanding that the City Council vote to extend the eviction moratorium amidst the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic on June 30, 2020 in San Diego, California.
media:content.media:credit: Sam Hodgson / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Santa Ana embraced a 'defund the police' movement. Then came the police union backlash
item.dc:creator: Adam Elmahrek
item.description: The experience of activists in Santa Ana who pushed to change funding priorities for police shows the fragile nature of such movements.
item.content:encoded: The experience of activists in Santa Ana who pushed to change funding priorities for police shows the fragile nature of such movements.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - JULY 17, 2020: Standing in front of a downtown mural, former Santa Ana city councilwoman Michele Martinez was involved in the "defund the police" debate only to have it be foiled later by a police union backlash on July 17, 2020 in Santa Ana, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: Chaos and incivility ruled the last day of California's legislative session. Blame Zoom
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: What happened in the California state Senate on the final night of the two-year legislative session Monday was a prime example of machines dispatching decorum and crippling civility.
item.content:encoded: What happened in the California state Senate on the final night of the two-year legislative session Monday was a prime example of machines dispatching decorum and crippling civility.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 28, 2020, file photo, Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Police officer charged with voluntary manslaughter in death of Bay Area man
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Jason Fletcher, a San Leandro police officer, was charged with voluntary manslaughter. Fletcher fatally shot Steven Taylor in responding to a shoplifting call.
item.content:encoded: Jason Fletcher, a San Leandro police officer, was charged with voluntary manslaughter. Fletcher fatally shot Steven Taylor in responding to a shoplifting call.

media:content.media:description: Alameda County Dist. Atty. Nancy E. O'Malley announces that her office will charge seven current and former Bay Area police officers in a sexual misconduct scandal involving a woman who now faces a battery charge in Florida.

item.title: Prosecutors begin dismissing felony cases involving LAPD officers accused in gang-framing scandal
item.dc:creator: Ben Poston, Kevin Rector
item.description: Prosecutors have begun dismissing felony cases that relied on the work of LAPD officers charged with falsifying records by claiming without evidence people they stopped were gang members.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors have begun dismissing felony cases that relied on the work of LAPD officers charged with falsifying records by claiming without evidence people they stopped were gang members.

media:content.media:description: Sgt. Al Reyes speaks to a new platoon of LAPD Metropolitan Division officers who were deployed as part of the department's effort to drive down the crime increase last year.

item.title: L.A. council backs a pay cut for many city workers, blocks request to target LAPD raises
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: L.A. officials want to furlough more than 15,000 city workers to help cope with a budget emergency amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: L.A. officials want to furlough more than 15,000 city workers to help cope with a budget emergency amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Councilman Mike Bonin has backed the idea of adding new fees for city permits to serve alcoholic beverages or provide entertainment at new restaurants and bars.

item.title: Three wounded in shooting at Santa Ana high-rise, police seeking shooter
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Santa Ana police officers responded to a shooting in a high rise Wednesday afternoon, finding three people with gunshot wounds but no shooter as of 4:30 p.m., authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Santa Ana police officers responded to a shooting in a high rise Wednesday afternoon, finding three people with gunshot wounds but no shooter as of 4:30 p.m., authorities said.

item.title: Attorneys for Dijon Kizzee's family say he was shot at 15 times as he ran away
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Attorneys for the family of Dijon Kizzee said he was shot at 15 times by sheriff's deputies in Westmont as he ran away
item.content:encoded: Attorneys for the family of Dijon Kizzee said he was shot at 15 times by sheriff's deputies in Westmont as he ran away

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 31, 2020. Residents face off with Sheriff's deputies hours after killing Dijon Kizzee in South LA. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: New at L.A. County libraries: Free printing and laptop and mobile hot-spot kits
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: You can now print things for free and borrow laptops and mobile Wi-Fi hot spots from select L.A. County Library locations.
item.content:encoded: You can now print things for free and borrow laptops and mobile Wi-Fi hot spots from select L.A. County Library locations.

media:content.media:description: A sidewalk service pickup at LA County Library. Services now include free printing and laptop and mobile hotspot loans.

item.title: L.A. County schools can reopen small in-person classes for their neediest students on Sept. 14
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Howard Blume, Sonja Sharp
item.description: County health officials said schools may offer services for small groups of students who have individualized education plans, are English language learners, or need assessments or specialized in-school services. The county will not be reopening the waiver program for students in grades TK-6.
item.content:encoded: County health officials said schools may offer services for small groups of students who have individualized education plans, are English language learners, or need assessments or specialized in-school services. The county will not be reopening the waiver program for students in grades TK-6.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Labels on desks designate where students can sit with respect to social distancing as Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California unemployment agency investigating potential widespread fraud
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers say there is growing evidence of possible widespread fraud in the state's unemployment benefits system, which is overseen by the Employment Development Department. The news comes as Californians report stalled jobless benefits from the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers say there is growing evidence of possible widespread fraud in the state's unemployment benefits system, which is overseen by the Employment Development Department. The news comes as Californians report stalled jobless benefits from the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Sorry we are closed sign board hanging on a door of cafe
